remarks:
Define a function that extracts the first member, or abscissa, of an ordered pair.  Theorem ~ op1st proves that it does this.  For example, ` ( 1st `` <. 3 , 4 >. ) = 3 ` .  Equivalent to Definition 5.13 (i) of [Monk1] p. 52 (compare ~ op1sta and ~ op1stb ).  The notation is the same as Monk's.  (Contributed by NM, 9-Oct-2004.) 

---

 Define a function that extracts the first member, or abscissa, of an ordered pair.  Theorem ~ op1st proves that it does this.  For example, ( ` 1st `` <. ` 3 , 4 ` >. ` ) = 3 .  Equivalent to Definition 5.13 (i) of [Monk1] p. 52 (compare ~ op1sta and ~ op1stb ).  The notation is the same as Monk's.  (Contributed by NM, 9-Oct-2004.)
statement: df-1st $p |- 1st = ( x e. _V |-> U. dom { x } ) $.
